reviewText: Twenty-six years ago,this comedy adventure premiered on CBS-TV. Reruns are currently seen on CMT(Country Music Television). Two decades ago,the show got the Nielsen axe along with The Jeffersons and Alice. Johnny Knoxville and Seann William Scott are cousins Luke and Bo Duke,portrayed respectively by Tom Wopat and John Schneider on the CBS series. However,SWS sports a beard. Despite their characters,Knoxville looks nothing like Wopat and SWS looks nothing like Schneider. Singing sensation Jessica Simpson is Daisy Duke,another cousin of Luke's and Bo's. Daisy is a blonde unlike her brunette TV counterpart,Catherine Bach. Bach is still a sexy beauty at age 51. Daisy is a waitress at the Boar's Nest,a pub and short order restaurant owned by Hazzard County Commissioner Jefferson Davis "Boss" Hogg(Oscar winner Burt Reynolds). Unlike the late Sorrell Booke who was Hogg on the series,Reynolds kept his trademark moustache(he sported a shorn goatee until later in the film). Another legendary entertainer is country star Willie Nelson who is Uncle Jesse,portrayed by the late Denver Pyle on the series. Deputy Enos Strate,service station attendant Cooter Davenport and Hazzard County sheriff Roscoe Coltrane were portrayed by either previously unknown or little-known actors,respectively. Memorable scenes include Luke and Bo hanging out at a girls' college,their impersonating foreign scientists and of course,their going out of their way,along with Daisy,to prevent construction of a new structure on the Dukes' farmland,which they almost lost. Only Boss and Roscoe were in favor of the construction. Also,take notice of Roscoe's basset hound Flash,who was much larger than the one seen on the series(from 1980 to the cancellation). I know the TV Flash was a female,but I don't know for sure about the film Flash. Because the series ended its run in 1985,the TV Flash has since died. And she debuted on the series five years earlier. During the end credits,Nelson performs GOOD OL' BOYS written by the late Waylon Jennings. Jennings performed the song in the opening montages of every episode in the series. In fact,Nelson and Jennings were longtime friends. They had a hit in 1978,MAMMAS,DON'T LET YOU BABIES GROW UP TO BE COWBOYS which they recorded as Waylon & Willie. Also,get a load of Bo's reckless driving of the General Lee. I don't know what kind of car was unsed in the film,but I know a 1969 Dodge Charger was used on the series. One song from this soundtrack is Simpson performing THESE BOOTS WERE MADE FOR WALKIN',which was a hit in 1966 for Nancy Sinatra(daughter of the late Frank). And of course,we see in the film,Luke and Bo racing the General Lee in a derby. None of the series' cast appeared in the film,but some,if not all(the survivors) have met the film's stars. Booke died in 1994 of a massive heart attack and Pyle died on Christmas Day 1997,his 77th birthday,of lung cancer. So I dedicate this film to their memories. This is one of few films that Reynolds did without(top)star billing. This film was distributed by Warner Bros.,the same company that produced the series.

reviewText: I'm not a fan of the old show, but enough of it floated through the cultural ether for me to get the general jist: two wily Southern boys with a outlaw mentality outwit the local corrupt establishment in a cool car. The movie is only vaguely related to that concept. Here, two guys with Southern accents as consistent as a flickering bulb bumble around doing mildly illegal stuff and are once again set against a corrupt local establishment. They are no longer smooth characters, they are, as another reviewer noted, kinda dumb (as Seann Williams notes in the outtakes when his cousin shares a pretty intense liplock with the girl he has secretly been shagging supposedly behind the back of smitten Williams's character--Oh, I'm a moron!), and rescued from the consequences of all their actions by deux ex machina.A particularly awkward set of scenes is where they take heat for the politically incorrect Southern battle flag on the roof of the General Lee. If the filmmakers wanted to take on the split cultural significances of the Stars and Bars, they should not simply played them for cheap laughs.But cheap laughs are the best part of this movie. And on that basis, I was well amused. I'm not surprised to learn that the director of the gutbusting (and far superior) Supertroopers was involved here. At its best, Dukes of Hazzard has that devil may care absurdist glee about it. It would have been a lot better if they had gone the whole hog and taken a really meta-revisionist axe to the project, making Williams and Knoxville latter day romantics about the legendary Dukes. For one thing, then we'd be spared the accents.So, on the one hand, this is the worst kind of shallow strip mining of cultural artifacts. On the other, its an entertaining romp with a likeable cast and a deft comedic hand at the stern. If in doubt, catch it on cable. I doubt I'll ever watch it again, but I don't regret the time spent with it either.Update: I'm a little confused as to why there are so many negative votes on my review. I can certainly understand disagreement, but is it truly unhelpful? I think I provided a useful gloss.
summary: Not as bad as you would think, not as good as you might hope

reviewText: The good news and the bad news: The Dukes of Hazzard movie is extremely similar to the television series it's based upon. No one ever gets hurt through all the stunts and cartoon violence, running moonshine comes off as a harmless bit of fun and most of the movie is watching amazing car stunts and ogling Daisy Duke.It could have been a lot different: Johnny Knoxville could potentially have brought a gritty vibe, and Seann William Scott could have brought a real gross-out appeal, but except for momentary nods in that direction, the show stays mostly true to its roots.Changing the tone more than the two leads is Willie Nelson as Uncle Jesse. In a nod to real life, Jesse sneaks in a little marijuana smoking (hinted at, more than shown in the rated version, explicitly shown in the unrated version) and brings a love of silly jokes to the proceedings -- the ad-libbed scenes of Willie Nelson telling Johnny Knoxville one silly joke after another, as he lobs flaming jars of moonshine behind the car is one of the highlights of the movie.Jessica Simpson does very little in this film, but it's exactly what you'd expect and, to be fair, she does it very well. Daisy remains sexy-but-not-slutty, just as she was in Catherine Bach's original version of the character. The 2005 rendition just is a hard-bodied version showing even more skin.In a nice update, the General Lee doesn't start off with the Confederate Battle Flag on the roof of the car, and once it appears, Bo and Luke are ambivalent about it being there (and it appears to be gone in the final sequence where the car is hidden in a field), and they get an earful about it while on the highway into Atlanta, both positive and negative.Burt Reynolds, whose Smokey and the Bandit movies are almost certainly responsible for the creation of the original TV show, is mostly wasted here, showing little of the oily charm he's been able to show even in lesser movies, like Striptease. Still, the Bandit turning Boss Hogg is worth a look, and a definite shout-out to the fans who've been watching this mini-genre of movies and television shows since the 1970s.A recommended viewing for fans of the original show or Smokey and the Bandit. A recommended purchase only for those who want to have footage of Jessica Simpson writhing around in a bikini (check the music video on the DVD for more) close at hand at all times.

reviewText: It is somewhat ironic that Amazon lists this item as a buyable companion to "Mr. and Mrs. Smith." While the two film's premises couldn't be more different, and if you only saw the trailers it is understandable to assume they play to completely different audiences (for instance, my parents would probably never rush out to see "Dukes," but given the plot and star power of "Smith" they made it a point to check that one out on opening weekend).Yet as I was watching "Dukes" and as I was compiling my thoughts to post here, I kept wanting to compare the two; making easy sumations like, 'just like Mr. and Mrs. Smith" "Dukes of Hazzard" is a typical, and typically dumb movie that somehow, in spite of itself, manages to be undeniably entertaining. In my "Smith" review I mentioned how unbelievably dumb the script was, combining lazy writing and plot holes you could drive a mack truck through, but the two leads were so charasmatic and the movie exploited every possible contrivence of its oulandish scenario to its maximum potential, that the movie was somewhat irresistable anyway.But if "Smith" was dumb and improbable on a great level, then "Dukes of Hazzard" has found a way to take that concept to a whole new level. Not only is the plot oulandish and improbable, it is also rahter nonexistant; an excuse to stage big chase scenes combined with typical fratboy humor. Like a lot of movies, you have seen this film before, only this time it is set in Hazzard County instead of on a college campus (although the film does make a brief detour to one)or some other genre clieche local. It's the same old thing, Mr. Big type (here its Boss Hog) will make a ton of money but will destroy the town in doing so. So it's up to the dimwitted leads to save the day. I'm not sure the Dukes actually do anything that helps matters all that much (they pretty much destroy everything they touch and land in holding cells through most of the movie), but I guess them looking busy doing something makes us think their actions are helpful.At least they are proactive.And the comedy is pretty thin, when you laugh you almost feel guilty for doing so because all the jokes and gags are either recycled, lazy or childish - often all at the same time. And yet, you will laugh. Why? As with the Smiths, the credit goes to the formidable cast. Hearing jokes as simple and comonly known as, 'why are divorces so expensive? Because they're worth it,' would be pretty lame if just tossed around in a movie to call it a comedy. But when Willie Nelson drops them his dry, good-ol-boy delivery, while chucking molitoff cocktails at cop cars, its pretty damn funny (of his joke, by the way, that is the only one I dare repeat in this forum).  The Dukes themselves are basically required to yell things like 'yee-haw!" and 'whoa,'  the later so much so they give Keanue Reeves a run for his money.  I wouldn't recomend creating a drinking game where the everyone drinks everytime said references pop up (because 10 minutes you'd end up with alcohol poisoning), but you certainly could.  But eveen though they don't get to flex their actor muscles much, the movie doesn't really require them too.  As long as they make for likeable and sympathetic troublemakers, they succeed at all the parts require.  Ditto Jessica Simpson and Burt Reynolds.  Not great performances, but adequate and often surprisingly better than you'd expect - if you're expectations are low.And that goes for the film itself.  My expectations could'nt have been any lower.  The reviews were lousy, I was not a fan of the TV series (I never much watched it because I never much liked it - of course, I was pretty young then, but TV Land reruns have not changed mind to this day), and I have no big fanfare in me for anyone in the cast.  I can see how die hard fans of the tv series would be disapointed; that is bound to happen with any remake of a favorite and if you thought the PG-13 version took things too far in comparison to the TV show then you'll want to avoid the Unrated version at all costs.But speaking as an outsider, as a typical dumb guys, hot girls, raunchy, car-chase comedy, "Dukes" works as well as any of its type.  As I said, credit the likeable cast, but I think director Jay Chandrasekhar deserves the bulk of the kudos.  The Broken Lizard comedy troupe vet, who gave as the similarly-toned "Super Troopers" works the same comedy magic here.  I have not seen the PG-13 version of this film, but I'd wager I would not have found it as funny.  Most of the laughs here come from that Broken Lizard style of comedy.  Low-brow, quick witted insults and gags involving drugs sex and car crashes.  Nothing in this movie falls into the quick witted category, but if it lacks that aspect of, say, "Super Troopers" it makes up for it with plenty more action and car chase sequences, all of them staged rather well from a comedy director.  The movie is essentialy one long car chase.  Best of all, some Broken Lizard vets pop up in funny suporting roles.  Without them to add to the comedy, just having the Dukes do their rather repetative thing, the movie may have grown stale and tired.So it's no comedy classic and at 107 minutes it feels too long.  But even though there is nothing special here, there are plenty of laughs and a suprisingly better/funnier movie than people like myself, who are not fans of the show, the cast and listened to reviews, could have predicted.  Thanks largely to great direction and likeable performaces,  overall, "Dukes of Hazard" is a dumb, but pleasant surprise.
summary: DUMB DUKES!  (but that's okay, they're just-a havin' some fun)

reviewText: I'll always defend the theatrical version of this film.But I can't at all defend this new Unrated Version.I didn't quite understand Ben Jones' anger when the film was released, especially his plea to fans to not see it until "it's cleaned up" to make it more like the "wholesome" original series (especially since the Pilot episode had inferences that Bo and Luke fathered some of the illegitimate children at the Hazzard County Orphanage).I went in with an open mind and enjoyed it immensely. Willie Nelson, for instance, practically steals every scene he's in, and his jokes had me howling.Is the film the same as the original series? No.....it's not meant to be. It's an entirely new interpretation, and I was able to overlook all the PG-13 language and sexual INNUENDOES.That having been said, I don't at all like what they've done with the Unrated Version. If this was the script Ben Jones was talking about, he was dead-on.  Plus, some scenes in the theatrical version actually worked better than those that replaced them (the final scene with Willie Nelson and Lynda Carter, for instance).While I'm not at all opposed to seeing FEMALE NUDITY, which this film has, I am opposed to seeing it, as well as anything more than innuendoes, sexual, drug use or otherwise, in any interpretation of the "Dukes." The deleted scenes even include Bo and Luke with marijuana, in a clear-cut scene not even open to interpretation.I was raised on the "Dukes of Hazzard" and always associate the show with my childhood. Too bad modern-day children won't be able to watch this Unrated Film.I can tolerate PG-13 material in a "Dukes" movie, but nothing beyond that.Please release the theatrical version in widescreen. reviewText: Movies are like buying cars - the advice about what car is "the best" really just depends on who your talking to...But I'd like to share my thoughts about this movie.Old fans of the Dukes TV series, you have to do one thing to enjoy this movie: Divorce Yourself From The TV Show !!! If you can't do that, you'll never be satisfied with ANY remake of the Dukes. Why? Well, read on...1) Very simply, the old cast is GONE. And if they were resurrected - as in a 25 yrs later Dukes - we'd have graying Bo & Luke, no Uncle Jesse or Boss Hogg, an overweight Daisy, etc etc. So the plot lines would have to be radically different.2) So, to keep the plot line what it was, there had to be a new cast. And absolutely no new cast of actors can capture the "exact" magic and chemistry of that original cast, no matter how the producers and directors finagle it.In other words, people who went to see the movie expecting the exact same show, exact same characters, and the old circa 1980 setting, were doomed to disappointment (and after all - what would be the point of a movie remake that's exactly what the show was??)...This is an entirely new Dukes of Hazzard, set in 21st century, and you must take it as such. "Jessica Simpson is lousy - not even a southern accent!" you say? Well, Catherine Bach (something of a TV icon; and well deserved) also had NO southern accent - in fact, hers is almost exactly like Jessica's! And both made wonderful Daisy's for their time.Uncle Jesse, played by Willie Nelson, sure ain't Denver Pyle's Jesse. But think about it - who else could've done better? I think Nelson did a great job!Point is, to watch this movie you must force yourself to stop comparing...and just enjoy the action !!

reviewText: I was a fan of the original TV show, but don't remember much of it, since I was in grade school at the time and haven't caught any reruns on cable. For sentimental reasons, I gave the "Dukes of Hazzard" movie a chance. It was worse than I thought it would be. It's not a good bad movie, just a bad movie. On the original show, I seem to recall that bad guys were the dumb ones and the good guys mostly did not act like morons. Here, the situation is reversed. All the while, the South is portrayed as the irretrievably backward place that it is not (which was pretty silly in the 1980s when the show was on, and it is even sillier now). The "Dukes of Hazzard" plays more like an episode of Knoxville's "Jackass" than the old TV show. The Duke boys are unsympathetic and self-destructive, and the stunts are not good enough to make up for a terribly unfunny script. Jessica Simpson carried herself rather well, I thought, and looked great doing it. But the film is truly bad. Fans of the much funnier "Super Troopers" will spot some of that movie's actors here (this film and "Super Troopers" have the same director). And anyone who went to LSU will recognize the campus (which subs for the University of Georgia.) But for the most part, this movie is dumb minus the fun. Spend your money and time on something else.

reviewText: The Dukes of Hazzard truly earns a place in the hall of shame of terrible, ill-advised remakes of previously popular TV shows.  Maybe, if you've never seen the show, you might think the movie is OK; the rest of us can only sit and cringe while Hollywood basically makes a mockery out of everything the show was about.  The script is bad in and of itself, but the casting is a total disaster.  I don't mind Johnny Knoxville and Seann William Scott so much, but Jessica Simpson is no Daisy, Burt Reynolds is almost the antithesis of the real Boss Hogg, Willie Nelson turns Uncle Jessie into some coarse country comedian you can't begin to respect, and Roscoe - what the heck happened to the Roscoe character?  James Best was one of the real stars of the television show; he made most of the comedy happen, and most kids included a Roscoe P. Coltrane impression in their comedic repertoire.  I've never even heard of M.C. Gainey, but he could never even begin to fill Best's shoes, even if the script had actually given us a character remotely similar to the original.  Maybe Burt Reynolds wanted to hog all of the bad guy spotlight; I can't think of any other reason why the Roscoe character would be treated with such contempt and neglect by the filmmakers.  And why is Lynda Carter even in the movie?Calling this modern Bo and Luke good old boys is stretching the point a bit; these guys actually should be in jail for all of their shenanigans.  Heck, the costs of all the property damage they inflict on Hazzard (not to mention Atlanta - which brings up another point: I'm almost sure the TV show was set in North Carolina and not Georgia) should be enough to bankrupt the county.  There's really nothing good about either one of them, especially in terms of their treatment of women.  It's safe to say that this film won't be found among Gloria Steinem's list of favorites.  As a Southerner, I'm not too happy with it, either, as the film went out of its way several times to basically ridicule Southern culture.  Then there's the fact that the Duke boys (and even Uncle Jessie) like to smoke something stronger than cigarettes.  Denver Pyle must still be spinning in his grave.  What's next?  An Andy Griffith remake featuring a drug-dealing Opie?The main problem with this film is the fact that it was primarily built around the General Lee and all the amazing jumps the studio guys dreamed of cramming together in one film.  They even messed even that up, unfortunately.  The jumps on the old TV show always looked real, but the jumps in the film are too high and too far to look like anything other than Hollywood stunts and special effects.  The only two things addressed in the DVD's extras of behind-the-scenes footage are the General Lee and Jessica Simpson's shorts.  Now I like watching Simpson gallivanting around in short shorts as much as the next guy, but I need a little more from a movie - something like a decent script, for example.There are plenty of reasons why loyal fans of the show as well as Ben Jones, the original Cooter and former U.S. Congressman, basically boycotted the film.  This rehash stomps on everything that made the Dukes cultural heroes of a sort and makes a mockery of every single character in the film.  If there's a film school out there teaching students how not to remake an old TV show, The Dukes of Hazzard is surely the main topic of study and discussion.  All you have to do is witness the General Lee hurling down the unpaved roads of Hazzard County to the music of AC/DC to know that something is very wrong here.
summary: A slap in the face to fans of the television series

reviewText: One reviewer described the new movie version of the TV "classic" "The Dukes of Hazzard" as "dumber than a bag of hammers." I saw very little to refute that evaluation. As a non-fan of the TV show, I only went to the movie because a friend worked on the crew and I hoped to see his name in the credits. Ho hum, it wasn't there, but several Louisiana settings were, including the Baton Rouge building in which I work. The "star" of the show is an orange late model Dodge Charger with a rebel flag painted on top, known affectionately to owner Bo Duke and cousins Luke and Daisy Duke, as the "General Lee." Bo and Luke spend most of the time riding around in the General delivering moonshine for "Uncle Jessie" (a waste of Willie Nelson's talent), and later in a race (what else) and on a mission to save Hazzard County (what else, part 2).Other than the shots of home turf and a decent Southern rock soundtrack, the two "boys" "highlight" the show. Bo, played by a scruffy young actor named Scott, has a well-developed love affair with "the General" and kind of a goofy charm about him. Luke, played by Johnny Knoxville (the name sounds like a country version of those movie stars on the Beverly Hillbillies--Dash Riprock and the like), is a little too old to be called a "boy", except in the Southern "good old boy" sense, but he's handy with a blow torch. Also to his credit, he's been smart enough not to sign up with the Hazzard County police department, who make the rest of the cast look like Nobel laureates.Besides Willie, other big-name stars are Jessica Simpson, who displays little talent aside from what can be seen sticking out of short shorts, low cut blouses, and a bikini; and Burt Reynolds, who plays against type in this kind of movie (see Smokey and the Bandit) as the scheming, white-clad Boss Hogg.Teenagers and grown fans of the original show probably won't be disappointed, if my daughter and stepson are evidence. There's cartoon violence, a little bad language, some talk about sex (including, surprisingly, sex with cars) and some implied drug use, but what even an 8-year old remembers will certainly be all the car crashes and jumps.Having no expectations, I wasn't disappointed (except for not seeing my friend's name), but I'd prefer that the movie business's resources be used on better projects that this one.

reviewText: When I was growing up, THE DUKES OF HAZZARD was one of those early 1980s TV shows that I watched every Friday night.  These days, I'm a bit reluctant to admit this fact as it was a pretty campy show.  But, it was fun & and I even remember my "cultured" father liking the show.  Here is yet another remake of a 70s / 80s TV show, made into a movie 20+ years later.The casting for the movie is decent with Seann William Scott as a natural for playing the cantankerous Bo Duke.  I found Johnny Knoxville a bit bland as Luke Duke - a definite downgrade from Tom Wopat.  Jessica Simpson fills in nicely as Daisy Duke, although I doubt if she's ever going to get any roles that are much different than this one.  It would have been a nice touch had they had a cameo or two of the actors from the original series.  If there were any cameos, I didn't see them.As you may have guessed, the plot is pretty contrived, but for a movie like this it works.  The Duke boys even take a road-trip to Atlanta, which is something that never happened in the series.  The original series was always filmed on back-roads in Hicksville.For those of you who might be curious about the unrated label, it's the road trip to Atlanta where it comes in.  I'm assuming that unlike the PG-13 theatrical release, this one shows numerous college coeds frolicking about topless.  I certainly had no problem with that particular element (notably absent from the TV series!).The biggest thing that they got right with this film was the GENERAL LEE.  Without question, it was the "star" of both the TV series and the movie.  It made the '69 Charger muscle car famous, and the film is not short on various ways to demonstrate the car's prowess.If you liked the original TV series, this movie is probably worth a look.  If you like party movies, this is most likely worth  a gander as they basically transformed the DOH concept into a hybrid story of redneck + party mentality humor.

reviewText: Unfortunately, the current Hollywood big studio practice of remaking TV series of yore into big-budget feature films has reached yet another nadir with this 2005 overblown cartoon of a movie. I should, however, give the movie credit for being perfectly clear on what it is, my backhanded way of saying some movies are deceptively marketed only to disappoint expectations (key example - the dismal update of "Bewitched"). This movie is what it is and nothing more. The source material was certainly not substantive, as the early-eighties series inspired by the movie was simply about two good ol' boy cousins named Bo and Luke Duke, who went on high-speed chases in their souped-up Charger named the General Lee. They were surrounded by stock characters like the nefarious Boss Hogg and aided by their moonshine-concocting Uncle Jesse and their shapely cousin Daisy in cutaway jean shorts.Despite the inane, derivative nature of its premise, there was some semblance of sincerity in the TV show that has been jettisoned here in favor of cynical bombast and teenage-oriented raunch. There is some hint of a plot involving Bo and Luke's plan to repair the General Lee and win the big road rally in time to stop Hogg's scheme to strip mine Hazzard County. However, nothing has been developed much beyond the premise. Casting poses a problem as well.  As the cousins, Johnny Knoxville and Seann William Scott are not very convincing as good-natured rednecks, as they seem more like MTV party-animal personalities masquerading as Southerners. Jessica Simpson is certainly an eyeful as Daisy, especially in a hot pink bikini, but she is hopelessly stilted when she is called on to say anything. It also seems a shame to waste Willie Nelson rather apathetic as Jesse save for his series of rim-shot redneck jokes, though the most embarrassing moments clearly belong to Burt Reynolds looking surgically altered and somewhat anesthetized as Hogg.Director Jay Chandrasekhar and screenwriter John O'Brien don't seem to have an ironic sense of the absurdity of the story (like director McG showed to some degree with the first big-screen update of "Charlie's Angels") and miss an opportunity for satire by simply poking fun at Hollywood-based Southern stereotypes. Even a genial ribbing of the TV series could have helped here, but it's obvious the studio executives prevailed as the tepid, by-the-numbers result confirms. Luckily for fans of this genre, there is an abundance of technically impressive, emotionally vacuous car chases. There are loads of bloopers and deleted scenes with the DVD package, some designed to be titillating with the "unrated" label, but the silliest extra may be "Daisy Dukes: The Short Short Shorts", which has the film's costume designers explaining how they made the (in)famous jean shorts. I'm serious.
summary: It Is What It Is...Uninspired Big-Screen Update With Car Chases and Oh Yes...Jessica Simpson

But the Dukesof Hazard always was a bit racey for some. Bo and Luke ran moonshinefrom their Uncle Jessie's still, Daisy was a little short on thewardrobe department, and Uncle Jessie was the leader of this motleyhillbilly moonshine gang that any "Revenuer" worth his badge would haveloved to have thrown in jail. The "boys" stayed in a constant state oftrouble, and flaunted their illegal activities in the face of local lawenforcement. These were NOT "good" boys!No, there was no marijuana use in the television series. It wasTELEVISION! They couldn't do that and be on television as a series.Frankly, I never loved the series. I thought it was hokey,unintelligent, and downright stupid. It made Southerners look like weARE inbred idiots. I detested it.As far as this modernization goes, I found it to be a 100% improvementover the cheesy dialog and horrible acting perpetrated upon us by theseries! The performances were great, the plot was in keeping with theoriginal series, the action...wow the action!This movie was a stunt-driver's wet dream! It was reminiscent (if onlya small bit) of Smokey and the Bandit in that it was great fun towatch. And while I enjoyed Jessica Simpson's Daisy Duke far more than Ithought was possible, she would have made a better Ellie Mae Clampett,in my opinion.It wasn't afraid to laugh at itself and never took itself tooseriously. Unfortunately, Burt Reynolds was a very weak Boss Hogg. Ihave no idea what they were thinking. The casting choice wasn'tnecessarily a bad call, but the direction of his character was justflaccid, as was Burt's performance. He played him too unemotionalwithout ever coming close to hitting the level of calculated treacherySorrel Brooke's Boss Hogg exuded. I felt that Mr. Reynolds wasjust...horrible in this endeavor, but Willie Nelson more than made upfor that in his portrayal as Uncle Jessie.So don't listen to the nay-sayers. This is a highly entertainingendevor. Even those of us of the "alternative" categorization could(and did) experience a few honest belly-laughs at our own expense.Heck, we survived "Deliverance!" I'm sure we'll survive this.The best line in the movie?"You're hillbillies!""We prefer Appalachian-Americans!"It rates a 7.6/10.

reviewText: Okay, first things first: the critics who bashed this movie obviously didn't like the show, because, take away a few cuss words and a bit more risque scenes, this is how the show is. So if you liked the show, you'll like the movie.I like the show. It's mindless fun with an awesome theme song and one of the coolest cars (and horns) around. The story for newbies: Luke (Johnny Knoxville) and Bo (Seann William Scott) Duke are two wild cousins in Hazzard County, Georgia who deliver moonshine in their famous General Lee vehicle for their Uncle Jesse (Willie Nelson). The sheriff in town, Roscoe, and his dimwitted deputy Enos, are paid by Boss Hogg (Burt Reynolds) to do his bidding (so basically, Boss Hogg runs Hazzard). Problems are caused when the Dukes' moonshine business is shut down, and the Dukes find out that Boss Hogg's planning to stripmine Hazzard. Oh, did I mention Luke & Bo's other cousin Daisy (Jessica Simpson), who gets the two out of tight spots with her, ahem, assets?Director Jay Chandrasekhar (part of the Broken Lizard comedy troop that did Super Troopers & Club Dread) does a great job translating the show to the big screen. The plot could have been one on the show, and everything you loved (the General Lee, all the characters, car chases, Daisy in revealing outfits, the hood slide, the theme song) is here. All the Lizards get cameos (one of them, with Chandrasekhar and Erik Stolhanske as cops on a college campus that echo their characters in Super Troopers, is a bit lame), the best of which Kevin Heffernan as Sheev, the dimwitted local who helps the boys and specializes in safecracking and making armadillo helmets.The casting is great: Knoxville & Scott are a fine Luke and Bo(although Luke now seems to be the ladies man, but Bo was in the show), Simpson was practically born to play Daisy, ditto for Nelson (who even sings the theme song at the end), David Koechner (aka Champ in Anchorman) is a great Cooter, Reynolds a perfectly sleazy Boss Hogg, and...well, whoever play Roscoe & Enos (I know that the guy who plays Roscoe was in Club Dread) do their jobs well. Well, that's it; y'all come back now, y'hear?
summary: Watch it if you're in a crawfish-boiling mood

You love Daisy Duke, The General Lee, moonshine, Uncle Jesse, and you think the Waylon Jennings theme song is just about the best damn song ever written. You can name the character cousins who replaced Bo and Luke Duke during their brief contract dispute with CBS, (the question stumped me during a recent Trivial Pursuit bout). You said a silent prayer when you heard two of the series stunt drivers were killed during a filming of one of the episodes, ending with, 'that great dirt back road in the sky'. You owned a Dukes of Hazzard T-shirt, the board game, official '69 Charger model kit, and you periodically check the secondary market of your Dukes of Hazzard lunch box.This movie loves the Dukes too. The cameras treat The General, that legendary orange '69 Charger, like a star in a fashion shoot, with long, loving, slow-motion shots and spectacular flying sequences, not only over country creeks, but highflying like a witch on a broom over highways in downtown Atlanta. Yee-Haw! There's more love here than a possum in springtime. A minor beloved character smiles directly into the camera after his bit, and who would have imagined that Daisy Duke's short shorts could become shorter? I can reluctantly admit that all essential characters, and then some, are accounted for, and the script is taken directly from episodes of the series, particularly the one about the successful hometown Hazzard boy who comes home to win the big race.The movie Dukes are a little dumber than TV's clean-cut Bo and Luke. Seann William Scott, as Bo, conveys a perfect simple-minded, big-hearted, gearhead country bumpkin, and Johnny Knoxville, aside from some lame and gratuitous stunt work, manages to fulfill the character, even with a wavering put-upon southern accent. The funniest role belongs to Kevin Hefferman as conspiracy minded, schizophrenic good ole boy, Sheev, who wears an armadillo shell on his head to block secret messages from the CIA. Jessica Simpson, as the leggy Daisy Duke, admits in the DVD extras that she only has to stand around and look good, and she does that well enough. The only grave disappointment is law enforcement bungling baddies, Roscoe and Boss Hogg, characters demanding broad slapstick are given careless and indifferent no-cigar treatment.So kick your shoes off, set down ahwile, the DVD extras reveal a dismantled and controlled General Lee, but dreams of a '69 Charger never die. When the sequel comes around, you'll be there faster than a polecat chased up a tree.
summary: THE GENERAL LEE AND A CAST OF HUMANS

reviewText: I'll start out by saying I'm not a purist.  But if you're going to take something as ain't-broken as the Dukes of Hazzard, you daggum well better know what you're doing when you try to fix it.  This movie has a lot of changes.  Some work well and some don't, but the end product isn't nearly as good as the source material.  It is a lot of fun if you don't think too hard about it.Any Dukes of Hazzard film is going to live or die by its car chases and especially the jumps.  Through most of the film they do not disappoint.  The jump onto the highway in Atlanta is one of the greatest jumps I've ever seen on the screen.  They just about ruin it all, though, with the last jump, a CGI atrocity.  When will filmmakers learn that just because it can be done in CGI doesn't mean it won't look like trash?  From the DVD extras, they actually did the real jump (with dummies), then ruined it with CGI.  And they planned to do the same with the rest of the jumps, but those looked so great even their own foolishness wouldn't let them ruin them.  A lot of the other car stunts are truly special.The filmmakers made some strange choices in adaptation.  The Dukes and their allies replace Boss Hogg and Roscoe P. Coltrane as the comic foils, but neither Hogg nor Roscoe (M.C. Gainey isn't half as scary as he was in Justified) can manage to be terribly menacing.  The movie (especially the unrated version) is also quite risqué.  I have no philosophical disagreement with that, but let's be honest--the Dukes don't need to go lowest common denominator to entertain.  I guess the thinking was that the old Dukes fans have all grown up, but the old Dukes formula would always be beloved by kids (and those of us that still like to pretend we're kids from time to time).Jessica Simpson tries hard, and fails, to look as good as Catherine Bach, but I'm not complaining.  Willie Nelson as Uncle Jesse just fires off one-liners.  The soundtrack is mostly southern rock mainstays, and it's a downright joy for country boy's when the General Lee fires up and Black Betty cranks up.Broken Lizard (of Super Troopers fame) eventually took over production.  They left many a hat tip to their marquee production.  Governor Jessman (Lynda Carter), the fast food cashier, and the Vermont state troopers from Super Troopers all make appearances.  There is also an allusion to the side-splitting opening scene.DVD extras include: Daisy Dukes: the short short shorts, the General Lee lives, how to launch a muscle car 175 feet in 4 seconds, the hazards of Dukes, the These Boots are Made for Walking music video, additional scenes, unrated additional scenes, bloopers, unrated bloopers, and the theatrical trailer.  Given the choice between this version (the Unrated one) and the theatrical version, I would prefer the latter.  The differences are across-the-board more risqué, but less funny.
summary: Fun, If Ultimately Unsatisfying Adaption . . . With Some Great Car Jumps

reviewText: No one can really be held accountable for wanting to see this movie.  As it is so common these days, the marketing dept makes the trailer look great using Spiderbait's version of Black Betty intercut with car chase scenes and Jessica Simpson kicking some rude sap to the floor (her best scene in the movie).  They made her look great.  They made the General Lee look great.  Ah, the genius of marketing.  Despite this, seeing the movie means dealing with a dumbed down version of the characters from the beloved show a lot of us grew up with.  First off I will say I thought the movie was a lot of fun.  Silly fun though, something you watch with your brain in low-brow mode.Now to compare it with the show (and if you make a remake, comparisons are going to happen), I can see why none of the original actors wanted to make a cameo.  First off, I didn't mind seeing Knoxville play Luke Duke, he has an insane charisma about himself that makes him watchable.  Scott was just fine as Bo, although his fear of talking to girls is totally opposite from the show.  Both looked really scruffy and low class, though.Overall, Bo and Luke are made out to be girl chasin', police avoiding, dim-witted, moonshine runnin' hillbillies.  Now, I don't have a problem with the girl chasing or running from police.  And Bo was the less intellectual of the two but made up for it with his driving skill which is reflected in the movie.  Luke was actually pretty sharp in the show.  But the real problem I have is that these guys are actually running Moonshine...what the hell?!  Now, I'm not a prude but this makes them criminals right off the bat.  And it was something that made you sympathize with them in the show; they were always being chased by the cops for something they didn't do, so you were rooting for them.  Moonshine running is something their Uncle Jesse did back in the day but stopped because he had to raise the three cousins and most likely wanted to raise them correctly.  And as a side note, how is it that one uncle gets stuck with three cousins?!  They each had their own parents.  They're all cousins.  This means Jesse had at least three siblings.  What happened to all of them?  Was it some tragically bizarre family reunion catastrophe that took them all?  If so, why weren't the kids there?  Why wasn't Jesse there?  Hmmm.But I digress.  Well, not totally.  Speaking of Uncle Jesse, the gentle soul of the TV show was a morally upstanding (possibly religious) citizen that scolded the boys (and girl) for saying `shoot' or `heck'.  He made them pray before eating.  He had them working on the farm for a living.  Now Willie Nelson steps in and cusses like a drunken sailor, throws Molotov cocktails into traffic, produces moonshine in a hidden room, tells dirty jokes and condones Daisy's language when she referrers to how she'll have to `shake her ass' in order to get the boys out of jail.  Did I mention he can't act?It seems the original concept of `good `ol boys' has been grossly reshaped.  Where the show used to imply it meant good southern people being mis-interrpreted and wrongly accused, the movie now implies that it means southern hicks who are just sly enough to keep from getting caught.  Unfortunately there is no sympathy for the latter, and in the end there isn't much to cheer for.However, comparisons aside, the movie is fun to watch if you never saw the show.  I have to give kudos to one scene of genius where the cousins have to go to Atlanta and while sitting in traffic are heckled by surrounding drivers either praising them or shunning them for driving a car with a confederate flag painted on the roof.  A truely accurate reflection of modern society.  That plus Jessica Simpson squeezing into the Daisy Dukes as well as the car chases are worth the price of admission alone, as long as you're going to a matinee and you have a two for one ticket.  Personally, I don't think any fan of the old show would like the changes to the characters even if they like the movie.
summary: Two and half stars for this Hillbilly character assassination

reviewText: What possesses a movie studio as powerful and respected as Warner Brothers to make a movie based on a classic, family-friendly TV show into a perverted, slap-stick ridden, raunch-fest of a comedy?  What blows my mind is how could anyone at this studio truly believe that this movie would be a good idea?  Who knows, but obviously someone thought it was movie-gold and that's why we are treated with this utter crap-fest starring raunchy comedians Seann William Scott ('American Pie Trilogy' and "The Rundown") and Johnny Knoxville (MTV's "Jackass" and "Men In Black 2"), along with country legend Willie Nelson, and sexy siren Jessica Simpson, known as "The Dukes of Hazzard"."The Dukes of Hazzard" follows the raunchy, dimwitted exploits of cousins Bo (Seann William Scott) and Luke (Johnny Knoxville) Duke.  Throughout their escapades, the cousins stumble upon a dastardly plot by the county's evil commissioner, Boss Hogg (Burt Reynolds), who seeks to level numerous farms in Hazzard County to begin a coal mining operation.  Discovering that their family farm is on the chopping block, the Dukes along with Daisy (Jessica Simpson) and Uncle Jesse (Willie Nelson) attempt to thwart this evil from occurring and become the towns heroes instead of zeroes.There are so many ways to describe just how bad this movie is, lets take a moment to list some of those ways.  Well, it's a boring, idiotic, utterly perverted, not even that funny, waste of time.  After watching this movie I felt like I was dumber from the experience.  The humorous elements, what little there was, comes not from the two lead actors, but from Jessica Simpson's Daisy Duke.  Out of the entire cast, not only is she the most attractive, but also the funniest, though to be fair I must admit that I'm probably being overly kind to her on account of her sex appeal.  There is very little about this movie that can even be deemed as entertaining.  It is evident that the director and the movie studio didn't set out to do an accurate adaptation of the classic TV show, but instead to make just another raunchy, teen comedy (except they forget to include the comedy).  The biggest sign that this adaptation was not even going to resemble the source material, other than the names of the characters and the car of course, is the fact that none of the main cast members from the TV show even make a cameo appearance.  There's generally at least a couple of cast members making appearances in remakes, but here we get nothing.So, in the end, if I was unable to convince you of just how crappy this movie truly is, and you still want to watch it.  Then by all means, knock yourself out, and after completing the movie seek help, because you need it."The Dukes of Hazzard" is unrated and contains violence, language, and nudity/sexuality.
summary: Lame and Perverted Remake of Classic TV...

reviewText: Ben "Cooter" Jones came out before this movie hit theaters telling fans of the TV show to skip this film adaptation for its raunchy sexuality that fails to pay tribute to "the family values" of the popular TV show. Considering that Mr. Jones was once my Congressman and someone I respected, I did keep his critique in mind as I watched this. I missed the film in theaters but knew I'd eventually see it on DVD for I thought the casting choice was very interesting.First of all, selecting Jessica Simpson as Daisy Duke won me over to this film. I like her and wanted to see if she could act, but disappointingly so, she's not that great of an actress. She does a passable job, though her main goal in this film was looking good for the camera. Her one-liners though should have been thrown out during the re-writes (were there re-writes?). Willie Nelson as Uncle Jesse was another interesting choice, but he was pretty much assigned to cracking some very raunchy jokes as he tossed explosives from the car. Linda Carter, another staples from 1970s television, has such a blink and you missed it role. Burt Reynolds as Boss Hogg? Interesting I thought, but no one could fill the original guy's shoes to begin with. Burt didn't even try. I miss the original Roscoe P. Coletrain's laugh/snicker. Seann William Scott (Stifler!) as Bo and Johnny Knoxville as Luke were also interesting choices. They did a great job, I thought, but it's hard not to mess this up, with all their innuendos and good ole boy fun.Now, about the adult humour...there was a gratuitious T&A; shot that I don't think worked, but the jokes were good fun. If you're going to bring an old TV show onto the big screen, it has to be different from the show. Either amp up the special effects, pick a great cast, have a brilliant script/story, or go for raunch that wouldn't make it past TV censors. Raunch wins the day on this one. The story is marginal, but works for this type of movie...Boss Hogg bends the law to steal Uncle Jesse's farm so he can strip mine the place; which happens during a very convenient car race to distract the citizens of Hazzard County from voicing their objections.What I like most about this film (besides Jessica Simpson in all her booty-shaking glory) is the scene in which other drivers make comments on the General Lee's rooftop Confederate Flag. We had that debate in Georgia a few years back and it was nice to see that kind of debate on film. I especially loved the detour through a rougher neighborhood as we get African Americans commenting on the Duke boys racist roof. I don't remember ever seeing a single African American on TV's Hazzard County, so it's a refereshing update for the modern era.The story line at the college in Atlanta was wasteful, and it's so obviously NOT Atlanta (New Orleans stands in for Atlanta) for those of us who live here...but other than that, the film is pretty funny in its raunchy humor and the good natured fun between Bo and Luke Duke. However, the whole time, I kept thinking of STIFLER! from the American Pie movies. Seann William Scott is in serious danger of typecasting forever if he doesn't branch out into other roles. I believe this is Johnny Knoxville's first acting role and I was surprised that he wasn't too bad. He probably has the most to benefit from this film.So, if you're watching this film, don't expect some high-brow entertainment. See it for what it is...just some good ole' boys, who don't mean any harm. If raunchy humor offends you, stay clear of this movie...but for guys like me, that's what made this movie better than expected. A little bit of raunch can go a very long way in keeping up the laughs. For the jokes that fall flat, there was Jessica Simpson's perfect form to ease the wincing pain of bad comedy.
summary: Good ole' boys that don't mean any harm!

reviewText: It was bound to happen and it finally has. "The Dukes of Hazzard" has now become a major motion picture and you know what, I loved it! As I've stated in several of my past reviews, Hollywood is on a remake kick that has lasted about ten years now and it shows no sign of slowing down. Ok, I'm not that opposed to taking the small screen to the big one so long as it's done right. I'm not sure if "The Dukes of Hazzard" was done right, but it contained some of the funniest scenes I've seen in the last few years. Granted the movie itself isn't that great, it's these scenes that have no place in the movie that make it funny and, yes, entertaining. For those familiar with the late 70's/early 80's show the plot will make absolute sense. And for those who aren't familiar with it, it'll take about 20 minutes and then the plot will make sense. The whole gang is here with Bo, Luke, Daisy Duke, Boss Hogg, Enos and Cooter. Dare I say it..."Yee Haw"!We meet Bo (Seann William Scott) and cousin Luke (Johnny Knoxville) as they're once again on the run from the Hazzard county sheriff's. A couple of jumps over streams later, they've escaped once again. They run moonshine, something that is evidently common even in 21st century rural Georgia. The plot, for lack of a better word, is pretty simple: The boys must save their farm from the evil Boss Hogg (Burt Reynolds) when they discover that he has plans to strip mine the town and benefit from the natural resources. Local celebrity Dil Driscoll (Michael Roof) will be doing a charity NASCAR-tupe event to distract the town while the strip mining matter is going through the appeals process in court. Long story short, there's everything that made the show fun. Plenty of good-looking women (and in the movie, many are naked), fast car chases and the perpetually drunk Uncle Jessie (Willie Nelson)."The Dukes of Hazzard" certainly won't win any Academy Awards, but I actually had a great time watching it. Jessica Simpson's physical appearance is to die for, but I don't think this chick has more than a handful of functioning brain cells (word has it that most of her scenes ended up on the cutting-room floor). Seann William Scott and Knoxville play very well off each other but the real treat here is the supporting cast. Cooter (David Koechner), Uncle Jessie (Willie Nelson) and Sheev (Kevin Hefferman) provide some of the funniest moments. The movie was directed by Jay Chandrasekhar who also directed "Super Troopers", a funny movie in its own right. Love `em or hate `em, the Duke boys are on DVD and for a good time, give this one a spin.A Dolby Digital 5.1 soundtrack is included as one might imagine, it's very active. Most movies have a car chase scene as their main focus, but "The Dukes of Hazzard" is pretty much one big car chase scene. As such all of the channels are vibrant with sound buzzing out of every possible speaker. Dialogue is clean, clear and if you've ever wanted to hear "Yee Haw" in 5.1 sound - now's your chance. The soundtrack buzzes with plenty of Lynard Skynnard hamering away in the background. Suffice it to say that Warner delivers again with this soundtrack."The Dukes of Hazzard" is shown in a very wide 2.40: 1 aspect ratio that looks great in all of its anamorphic beauty. Being a big budget film and a new to DVD release, I was expecting a good-looking transfer and I'm pleased to say that Warner has delivered. Colors are rich and vibrant and the level of detail is amazing. Most of the scenes take place during the day so there's no risk of any low light areas to compromise the transfer. As the ending credits roll, there's an outtake in which Joe Don Baker says "Every time I look at her (Jessica Simpson's) tiddies, I forget my line". Well, the transfer is certainly good enough to make any person watching forget their line...The extras are plentiful, but ultimately lacking in substance; then again this is "The Dukes of Hazzard" we're talking about here, so it kind of makes sense. First up, this is the "Unrated" version with additional footage not shown in theaters. Not having seen the movie in theaters, I can only guess what was added for this extended cut. There are two sets of additional scenes, a "PG-13" version and some "Unrated" versions as well. The unrated ones will let you take a peek at some topless sorority girls - I'd advise watching those. There are three featurettes: "Daisy Dukes: The Short Short Shorts" in which we see Jessica Simpson and how she got in shape for the part (evidently she had to work out to get her size down to get in the shorts) and even a tutorial on how to make your own. "The General Lee Lives" shows us a good portion of footage and how this 1969 Charger has become one of the most famous in the world. "How to Launch a Muscle Car 175 feet in 4 Seconds" shows us just that - how they pulled off those jumps. They must have gone through a lot of cars and shows us that the Dukes would have been dead several times over if the stunts were real. There are a couple of gag reels, Jessica Simpson's "These Boots are Made for Walkin'" music video and the obiligatory "Making of..." featurette. While this movie might not enlighten you like others, break out the moonshine and give this disc a spin. Yeehaw!
summary: Great unrated DVD release of a fun, thought-free flick!

reviewText: It seems many fans of the original `Dukes of Hazzard' hate this new film version. I never saw the original TV when it was televised in Japan, and have no intention to make any comparison between the two, but still I also could not like the film, and found it very lame and unfunny. Film remake of "The Beverly Hillbillies" was pretty unfunny (in a literal meaning), but this one's unfunny' easily surpasses it with more disastrous results.In a nutshell, the film is about Duke cousins and their buffoonery. These `good' boys Bo (Seann William Scott) and Luke (Johnny Knoxville) deliver moonshine manufactured by Uncle Jesse (Willie Nelson looking exactly as Willie Nelson), and stop the schemes of Hogg (Burt Reynolds ... oh dear). The pedestrian story and faceless supports are of no use here, especially when most of the humor of the film belong to those of amateur comedians whose only trick to cry, yell, be offensive, run around, and finally destroy things on stage.You can also see Jessica Simpson who is not required to do much except to look sexy, but if you're interested in her alone, you can save your time by watching her music video ans listen to the uninspired cover version of one Nancy Sinatra hit song.[THE GREATEST THING IS ... THE CAR] But the real hero of the film is the `General Lee' driving wildly on the country road and flying high up in the air occasionally. Unlike the typecast actors, this red car knows how to entertain the viewers with good stunt works. But even the great work from the stunts are undermined by the lengthy story and underwhelming finale. Even `Herbie' and Lindsay Lohan know how to wrap up the film with more decent car race scenes.I know Scott and Knoxville are both better actors than their previous works would suggest. It is true that they and their OK performances are not to be blamed for and confused with the badly stereotyped Southern people and its culture, but still they are responsible for what they choose, and this kind of mistake could kill the career someday.`Dukes of Hazzard' is a forgettable and derivative comedy from the director of `Super Troopers' which I think is overrated, but still better than this. Or you can watch the original TV 'Dukes,' enjoy yourself, and save your precious time.
summary: Once Again, Hollywood Remake We Don't Need (But the Car Is Great)

reviewText: What happened to the Dukes of Hazzard? If you are like me, this was one of your favorite shows in the 1980s and it just got butchered! BUTCHERED! I knew it was going to be bad when I saw the trailer and I heard of who was going to be cast in the movie, but I rented it hoping to be surprised.I like Sean Williams Scott and Burt Reynolds but neither resembles the character that they are playing in the original movie. Johnny Knoxville at least looks mildly like Luke even though he spends more time jumping in and out of bed with the women in this film than he does anything else. I could have a faulty memory but I don't remember that from the TV show. And Sean Williams Scott is practically a-sexual as Bo in this movie, which is SOO not how I remember Bo being. When I was a kid, Bo was one of the primary reasons I watched the Dukes of Hazzard because he was HOT and his character didn't seem like an idiot (which this Bo is).I like Jessica Simpson as a singer, but she doesn't convey the intelligence of the original Daisy Duke. While Daisy was always a sex symbol on the show, I always thought that Daisy was highly intelligent and sometimes I thought she was smarter than Bo and Luke. There is barely a part for Daisy in this film. The only thing she does is skimp around in little outfits to distract people from what the men in her family are doing.Burt Reynolds was sinister in this movie, but not as fat or as funny as Boss Hogg from the show. Boss Hogg's assistant Cletus was completely unlike the TV show character who was hilarious!To me, this movie was a chance to throw together three attractive people, skimpy outfits, pointless boob shots, and some interesting car chases into a movie. I wondered in the back of my mind if the actors and director had even watched the original Dukes of Hazzard. I say if you buy this, buy it because you like these actors or you like the General Lee, don't buy it because you want to re-live the television experience. You can now buy all seasons of the Dukes of Hazzard on DVD, so just use your money to buy that instead.

reviewText: THE DUKES OF HAZZARD was okay and delivered on the grounds of its target audience (Does this target audience still exist?). However, if one remembers the original series, Bo and Luke Duke (John Schneider & Tom Wopat respectively) were not the idiots as portrayed in the film version (played by Seann William Scott & Johnny Knoxville). Bo and Luke in the tv series were usually played straight, intelligent and the "calm in center of the storm". They were likeable characters. The movie Daisy Duke and Uncle Jessie (Jessica Simpson and Willie Nelson) are pretty close to their tv counterparts while Boss Hogg (Burt Reynolds) and Sheriff Roscoe P Coltrane (MC Gainey --tv's LOST--one of "The Others") are way off from their original tv portraits. Bo/Williams & Luke/Knoxville are irritatingly mean-spirited and unlikeable throughout the film.  Directed by Jay Chandrasekhar of "Broken Lizard" (SUPER TROOPERS, BEER FEST), so one can get a good idea on what the atmosphere of this film is going to be like. A few of the "Broken Lizard" troop even a appear in the film (and apparently did some of the rewites on the script). The plot revolves around the Duke's farm being taken away from them by Sheriff Roscoe P. Coltrane and Boss Hogg, and the Dukes must get it back. Also, there is a NASCAR race coming to town and the Dukes must get "The General Lee" (the famous Dodge Charger) tuned up to win a big race. Overall, there are a few laughs courtesy of the "Broken Lizard" influence of the film, Jessica Simpson is a always nice to look at while filling out those "Daisy-Duke" shorts just fine, and the classy Linda Carter (tv's WONDER WOMAN) rounds out the cast in a supporting role.
